author: {'steamid': '76561198077398527', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 11198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11198, 'last_played': 1698746832}
review:
Это не столько отзыв, сколько мысли в помощь новым игрокам. 

1. Как и все игры, эта игра на высоких уровнях сложности выставляет от балды (off-map) вражеские армии. В отличие от других игр, с момента уничтожения предпоследнего противника (т.е. когда вы остаётесь один на один с последним оппонентом) она резко увеличивает количество и качество юнитов, выставляемых off-map. На высшем уровне сложности это приводит к развалу вашего фронта в течение нескольких ходов. Разумеется, я пишу по личным впечатлениям. 
Это означает, что добивать предпоследнего противника нельзя. Надо ослаблять короткими ударами каждого из двух последних противников поочерёдно. Цель ударов – не уничтожение юнитов (они все равно выставляются от балды), а разрушение производственных центров (например, заходя с моря леталками). 

2. В Gladius обеспечение потребностей населения и производства настолько хитро устроено, что при каждом расширении города выпуском боевых частей  занимаются не более четверти новых граждан. Кроме того, основание новых городов сильно понижает продуктивность общую продуктивность. Та же модель, что в поздних Цивах. Иными словами, спираль развития не расширяется, как в классических 4Х, а сужается – но сразу заметить это сложно. Мне, во всяком случае.
Так что играть только с одним городом имеет смысл не только ради ачивки Chapter Approved: это просто эффективно. 

3. Время, потребное на производство топового юнита, всего в 2-3 раза больше, чем самого базового. То же касается и ресурсов. Сравните с первой Цивой, где разница была 16-кратной. Таким образом, в Gladius имеет смысл пропустить фазу строительства базовых юнитов и как можно скорее перейти к производству топовых войск. Это самый прямой способ выиграть на уровне выше "трудный". 
Как это сделать? Враг же не дремлет?
Во-первых, сразу постройте три-четыре исследовательских центра. И еще при формировании мира снизьте до минимума стоимость исследований.
Во-вторых, максимально отдалите момент появления вражин возле ваших городов: играйте на большой или огромной карте; уменьшите число компьютерных игроков до трёх (если два, то один быстро сожрет другого и вы останетесь с ним один-на-один со всеми отсюда вытекающими последствиями); сделайте больше труднопроходимых участков (имперские руины, реки, wireweed) и воды (для этого надо максимизировать соотношение размеров мира к суше). Но главное, выкрутите на максимум уровень активности нейтралов (wildlife). В Gladius компьютерные оппоненты не умеют эффективно сражаться с нейтралами, а нейтралы честно нападают на всех игроков, не только на человека. Увеличение количества нейтралов на планете пойдёт вам на пользу при любой стратегии. 

4. Gladius получилась неплохой, потому что разработчики использовали в ней уроки, полученные в ходе долгого исправления их предыдущей игры, Pandora. Теперь они ставят тот же движок на свою новую игру, Zephon. Так вот, судя по демо-версии (2023), Zephon ничем от Gladius не отличается. Механики те же. К сожалению, многие студии, в надежде без труда поднять копеечку, выпускают не новую версию игры, а перелицованную старую.

Уже много букв, надо закругляться. Если хотите, посмотрите еще мою книжку "Военные стратегии в компьютерных играх и реальном мире". Там не только про "Гладиус".

review:
Imagine a simplified Civ game, with no trade or diplomacy, and only war. You can only win through or by completing your story objectives (e.g.  visiting 3 select tiles after building a Weirdboy). It also offers a lot of adjustment when you begin a game through various parts of its difficulty, map size, and landmass volume, and teams. You can also select whether you play with someone and/or whether the AI opponents get bonuses/minuses and what faction anyone is. The base game gives you 4 faction options with relatively unique playstyles. Harder factions to play are generally more rewarding in the late game while easier factions tend to be strong in the early game. They are also just easier or harder to understand and manage in general. 

This game also has various additional factions, units, and constructions available in its DLC and while they may seem expensive, many of them can be worth it due to your potential playtime with each one and how they spice the game up. It also helps that they go on sale occasionally with a decent discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033476313', 'num_games_owned': 854, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 9845, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9845, 'last_played': 1710964456}
review:
Should my profile pic and/or name not betray me already, I pretty much grew up with WH40k strategy games, starting with Dawn of War 1. Which would make me recommend Gladius, obviously.

Bias aside, what is it, and could it speak to you ?

Basically, think of it as the violent person's alternative to Civilization 5 or 6. Out of all the Warhammer 40k games, this may be the closest one to the "There is only War" mantra : No diplomacy, not even discussion, just fighting. Everything on Gladius wants you dead. 

The other factions, obviously, with a surprisingly good AI (most of the time), but the wildlife too (With its giants bugs, mind-controlling bugs, flying egg-laying bugs, giant murderbots, bug cultists, murder cultists and ... eldritch accumulation of pure nothingness. And gun-totting bugs.). Even the landscape hates your gut, and in pretty Warhammer over-the-top fashion, you'll be avoiding bushes with thorns so sharp they eat through your Superheavies armor.

Sure, there are your 4X, but the emphasis is put on eXterminate, here, and everything serves that goal ...

But compared to Civ, the differents factions are wildly different, with their own quirks and unit rosters : Tall and Elite-focused Space Marines, Turtling and vehicle-focused Imperial Guard (or Astra Militarum, if you want the correct denomination), spammy Orks and ... "Classic" Necrons (Yes, in Gladius, the beginner friendly faction are Terminators cosplaying Ancient Egypt)

And that's only for the base game.

Which may be my main grievance against the game, along with its optimization : the amount of DLCs.

They're varying in quality, and if you're not into Warhammer that much, most of them probably won't speak to you. The faction one are pretty interesting, however, with even more game styles covered, from the Tyranids (Bugs. Because of course) literally eating the planet and spamming even harder than the Orks, to the infantry-focused Adepta Sororitas (Space Crusading Nuns) slapping every buff imaginable on every unit through the power of Faith(tm), to the Aeldari (Space Elves) literally turning the flow of the game on its head with a roster comprised of glass cannons able of shooting before moving ... 

There is something for everyone here ... But if you're not here for the IP and not willing to sink all your money in DLCs, you'll probably have to do your homework and find which faction may talk to you the most. (Also, just avoid the God of Skulls DLC. You'll save a couple of bucks, trust me.)

In conclusion, if you want a bloodthirsty alternative to Civilization with better combat and more variety in said combat, go ahead. Same thing if you want a "Warhammer Civilization" not burdened by non-combat mechanics.

If you're not into Warhammer and expecting a typical 4X, however, Gladius may not be for you.

review:
Что могу сказать, игра точно не стоит своей стоимости, если её и стоит покупать, то только по скидке
Обычная пошаговая игрушка, напоминающая цивилизацию, но с бОльшим упором именно на битвы. Весь геймплей это: построил здание, в нём нанял подразделения, нашёл врага, уничтожил все его города и победил (и всё это параллельно с исследованием новых зданий, войск и их улучшений) . Игра максимально простая для любителей стратегий. Также заметил, что во всех фракциях нет исследований для разблокировки определённых подразделений, однако если начать игру с исследованиями определённого уровня, то тогда они будут доступны (например освежеватели, духи, снайперы, бессмертные у некронов, скауты и какие-то крутые парни у космодесанта и т.д.). Из-за этого появляется ощущение, что игра ещё просто не доделана, однако к ней УЖЕ можно купить ДЛС, что говорит об обратном. В целом игра не совсем плоха, однако брать её я не советую. Может в будущем что-то изменится.

review:
Pretty basic turn-based strategy game.


But it has creedy monetization that makes no sense.

In base game you receive space marines, astra militarum, orks and necrons. But technically don't, since it has paid DLC packs that contain +1 new unit for each faction. This included DLC factions, so you have DLC that acts also as DLC to other DLC.

review:
They took a lesson from EA and the sims, selling a barebones base game at 'game of the year, all dlc included' levels of price.
And then dare sell the multiple dlc that are required to make the game playable for 15 euro each.
The base game includes four races, but only a few ranged units, tanks and heroes.
for an expanded roster with more melee, air, heavy suport, extra heroes and defensive units you will need to pay for separate DLCs.
And then there are race dlcs.

And thats just the storefront side of things.
The game itself is barebones and janky.
The UI is lacking, there is no queueing orders for troops, if you accidentally order two buildings to be build in the same place the game lets you do that but only finishes the first one, the second building dissapears and the game doesnt tell you.
The balance is whack with units doing 1.5 damage each turn to units with 20 to 30 health.
The terrain is badly telegraphed and i cant tell what is important or not, what will hinder movement or is a resource or a building.
You cant queue research, which is "bought" for "research income" so you can finish a research in a single turn if you have enough saved up or in income but you cant make a queue so that the surplus goes somewhere.
If you reach critical mass with research there is just no point in getting more.
The same applies for the other resources as well.
Why do i want more food?
The growth of population doesnt seem affected by it.
Why do i want "influence" if i dont have any political actions?
Why do i want more power as a race that barely uses it?
What do i do with all my surplus?
It feels like they just threw in all the tropes that all the other hexagonal strategy games have with no thought as to why they are there.
And the "story" is superficial with arbitrary goals and no real rewards.
"build a barrack" and gain 10 ore.
"make a unit" and gain 10 influence.
"Do a research" and gain 10 food.
And then, all of a sudden;
"The tech priest has betrayed you, you dont know why, kill him" reward: Victory. (yes, thats the actual last mission)(???????)
I wouldnt even buy this on sale and would return it if i could.

review:
One of the better 40K offerings. Plays like a cross between Civ and Panzer General/Panzer Corps. No diplomancy of course since "there is only war" etc. Units do require tactics to use effectively, also they can gain experience and leaders can gain special abilities and equipment. 

You do build cities like Civ but their only purpose is to gain resources or allow production of different troops or vehicles. The exception is Space Marines who can only ever build one city.

Graphics are okay but things do look a bit muddy at times namely the terrain. Units are pretty accurate if you've ever played 40K tabletop. Sound effects are mostly serviceable, although certain things like the bolters sound great. Lack of unit  voices does reduce immersion for me but can be mostly fixed by the fantastic 'Too Many Voices' mod on the workshop.

There is no actual campaign, its just a series of chained missions on the same map with a little story text. However as a skirmish game it can be a lot of fun. Another positive is that all the races play differently and have their own unique mechanics. 

One con: Too much DLC and it is a bit overpriced. If you like the game just pick up any DLC that interests you when its heavily discounted.

The procedurally generated maps ensure that no two games are alike, keeping the experience fresh and challenging. The strategic layer, with its focus on resource management and city building, provides a solid foundation for the intense tactical battles that unfold on the battlefield.

The attention to detail in the game's lore and visuals is impressive, capturing the dark and gritty atmosphere of the Warhammer 40,000 universe. From the intricate unit designs to the desolate landscapes of Gladius Prime, every aspect of the game is steeped in the rich lore of the Warhammer 40,000 universe.

Overall, Warhammer 40,000: Gladius - Relics of War is a must-play for fans of Warhammer 40,000 and strategy games alike. With its challenging gameplay, deep lore, and multiplayer support, it offers a rewarding and immersive experience that will keep you coming back for more 👍⚡️👌.

review:
The modders, as usual, make this game pretty darn good!

It's a good overall design, has moments of engagement and enjoyment, is replayable to heck (Even just the base game without the pricey DLC ) and has a Workshop where Battlesector (A cross promoted game by same publisher) doesn't for some reason...

I purchased years ago but had an older laptop that didn't use Vulkan drivers so, a regretable refund at the time as game wouldn't load.  It seems simple but can be quite demanding on hardware when things really start lighting up across the battlefields in the game. Be aware of this before purchasing.

The only criticism I'd have is that the Devs/Publisher, whatever, reduce the DLC cost.   I would maybe buy only one (Faction type DLC not the others, which I have bought a few of) without mods available.  I am only buying them in the future on sale, steep sale...in the future, due to the mods on offer now that kind of require them at times.

I wish there was a bit more functionality in the design of the individual units, such as mixed weaponry and models visually representing that, say a Terminator unit for example : Powerfists, Assault Cannon/other; Whirlwind launchers, Heavy flamer etc...;,   It is supposed to be large scale representation but would add some flavour for sure.

Overall, on discount and at its base with mods (I do own some of the cheaper DLC assault, Fortifications etc...) it's a steal.  I have had hours and hours of enjoyment during downtime this week and for that, I do recommend it.

Also, the community is pretty top notch, you generally get real 40K fans here, probably most enjoyed the game Epic 40K back in the day.   This game is as close as you will get to it.  Hope they make a campaign system at some point : )

Thanks!

review:
Underrated! Like Civ 5 in domination-only mode, set in 40K. If you're looking for a turn-based strategy game, I highly recommend you give this a try if you've enjoyed civilization games or even 40K RTS games. The gameplay is 10/10, easily. 

A behemoth studio could try to make this game, but it would be shit. It would have ragdoll physics, built-in voice-overs for all units (even though not needed for a TBS game), the lore would be bastardized, and the gameplay would be designed for a 12-year-old.

Unit voice-overs, which are probably one of the most beloved features of the 40K RTS games, are lacking in the base game. However, there is a good quality mod (Too Many Voices) made by several voice actors, fans, and audio people.

I also recommend you get the Cities+ mod (visual size adjustments), along with checking out the texture packs (may not be to your preference). Some reviews complain about the cost of the DLC. Well, there are regular sales, so just wait for one of those.

I highly recommend going to your installation folder \data\audio\blueprints\mixer.xml
right at the top, change rolloffFactor="4" to rolloffFactor="2". This will diminish how quiet sounds get when you are zoomed out. This will save your ears when you zoom in to see the action, as you'll have set a lower effect volume to compensate.

Warhammer 40K Gladius is a turn based RTS that seems similar to Civilization but is oriented more towards the war part instead of diplomacy or economy and while it sounds like it would be great and fun,there is an issue that i'll talk about at the end.

As graphics go,it looks pretty good,some of the units are drawn really accurately and with all the different color pallets you get to experience all sorts of lore friendly troops,the terrain is textured nicely and you get to tell if some places have positive or negative passives just by looking at them,the outposts are differentiated well,it's good and well made after all.

Soundwise,the biggest issue is that in order to really make the game shine,you will have to get some mods from the steam workshop in order to have proper voicelines for most of the characters,which is really sad considering how much an RTS game works on voicelines,but everything else is done well,the music is also decent,just has that one issue.

There's barely any story,you can just get some bits and pieces of lore by playing the factions or reading stuff around,but most of the missions are just randomly generated based on your selections,be it map size or number of enemies or all the other settings you can tweak around.

Gameplay is what really brings the game to shine a bit more,because there will be lots of fights and many wars to be won,but you will have to manage your resources quite well,while also pushing for more outposts and defending the tiles that you grab. It sounds easy,but there's a minor issue with all that.

The DLC's are mostly just a whole new faction,but the overall joy and pleasure is mostly achieved when you get to fight all of them at once or have a friend play with you in a hard 2vs4 scenario,but the lack of some of the factions really cuts the replayability after a while,because the strategies won't just change overnight.

You have the classic infantry for almost all the factions,but with different playstyles,the resources they use are also different,the way they expand is switched up,which do bring new situations or difficult choices,cause they might bring you an easy win or a total defeat.

The fights and the expansion happens on tiles,same as in Civilization,with all the troops having different ranges or skills that might only work in close combat or fire extremely far,but just as you can use all those,your opponents can do so as well,so learning some of the more common units surely helps securing that juicy victory.

Overall,i'd say that Gladius - Relics of War is a good RTS game,but heldback by the pricey DLC's that should either have a lower price or bring just a tad more to the table,and also the fact that some mods are just a must in order to have a much better game than the original,so waiting for some sales would be the best move you can do regarding this title.

This game is very comparable to Sid Meier's Civilization - the good (turn-based tactical management & strategy) and the bad (too many pricey dlcs you want or need to get everything out of the game,) except the only victory conditions are "kill everyone" or "complete a series of personalized objectives for your faction". I could go into more detail, but honestly? I don't need to. It's good, but overpriced. I'll go into a bit more detail anyways, though.

If you like Sid Meier's Civilization and games like it, odds are very high you'll like this: it's a very well done turn based tactics/city management strategy game with lots of different factions to get into that each play very differently. Balancing is solid for the most part (poor IG are just really weak here) and the variety of tactics, strategies and general tools you have access to are very well handled. Relic has done an excellent job of capturing the 40k vibe with this game and it manages to incorporate the "kill everything that moves" victory condition into a game of this size and scope much better than I feel Civ ever really did-- it doesn't take a million years of back and forth for one player to kill everyone else without relying on a "win button" like nukes, which is very nice. There's also an active mod community and workshop, who provide a much more customizable experience. Multiplayer also automatically shares all DLC owned by the host with all clients, meaning only one member of your friend group needs to buy the dlc for the whole gang to use it together, in vs or co-op. However if that one friend with the dlc is missing, the rest of the gang will be stuck with baseline content.

Again my only real complaint with this game is the scummy dlc packaging; the base game ($55 cad) gets you 4/11 "full" factions, with the other 7 factions being individually packaged DLC ($22 cad each) and several unit packs (ranging from $7-$12 cad each) introducing new, often very important units to every faction (The Space Marines, one of the four base factions, does not have a super unit unless you purchase the appropriate unit pack). 

Gladius is an easy recommendation, but a hard sale. If you can grab the game on a big sale - like during the holidays - and grab as much dlc as you can it's a wonderful experience and will keep you coming back for more. However the entry fee is much too steep and will push away most potential players. It's a shame, as it is a very good game in it's niche.

**At time of writing, the most recent DLC release is the Dark Eldar. It's nice to see the game still getting new content a whole 6 years after it's release, though the price is still higher than it should be.

review:
В общем казалось бы? Еще одна пошаговая игра... Но когда меня отмочили на учебной миссии, я сказал - огого!
Попробовал и так и эдак - и нажал капитулировать. И тут мне показали график развития меня и оппонента... И я такой - гдето я такое видел... И потом - это же как в Цивилизации!!!

После этого игра стала понятнее. Т.е. вы и противники можете развиваться как вам вздумается, но если у противника получится лучше... тут за одну две битвы это переломить не получится. увы.

Тем кто играл в цивилизацию - это интереснее, и с большим упором на битвы и боевые юниты. Мне понравилось.
Для тех кто не играл - интересная пошаговая стратегия, когда сражение за зоны влияния и технологии не дают расслабиться всю игру. Очень затягивает

#######

После пары игр.
Значит несколько моментов:

1. Как и в циве, вы можете быть с вашим противником примерно одинаково развиты. Поэтому у вас формируется "линия фронта", где сражение идет прям не переставая. И тут любое достижение в развитии технологий имеет значение. Т.е. одна игра может напоминать армрестлинг. Те кто любит сложности - оценят

2. Здесь есть герои, и им можно приобрести артефакты. Это важная штука, т.к. она может переломить исход битвы. Ну если вы их не угробите конечно сразу.

3. Карты красивые, и пока повторений не было. Чувствую - это надолго.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006598066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 2473, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2408, 'last_played': 1708533712}
review:
The game simply doesn't flow ... That's really the short of it.

Everything is tedious. Wildlife significantly limits you in the early game. You build masses of units, just so they can stand in the way of each other when attacking or defending. The solution would be easy. Just let my units move trough each other. Done. Enemy units and buildings take way to long to kill, resulting in a constant back and forth on the battlefield, and questionable worth of really any unit. It takes relatively long to build said units, unless you waste building slots by creating several production facilities of the same type. Most units cannot move far enough per round to make a difference of any kind. Everything just feels so cramped.

It's nice that this game tries to cover every faction of WH40K and gives them sort of a narrative campaign, but the gameplay and even the UI is severely unpleasant and hampered.

review:
Es un buen juego de estrategia, eso si el tutorial no explica con detalle como debería, el numero de turnos que tienes que esperar para crear a una unidad es una locura, hasta que lo configuras a una velocidad rapida, para que tarde dependiendo del terreno que te encuentres, de 2 a 3 turnos. Eso lo hace aceptable.
Ya pobre todas las facciones de este juego y todas me encantan.
Si no quieres batallar para gestionar todo lo que son recursos, entonces te recomiendo, Tyranidos y Necrones
Si quieres una fuerte milicia con mucho poder de fuego y defensa todas las facciones de la humanidad, Necrones e incluso Caos.
Si quieres una milicia con un ataque agresivo, los elfos oscuros, Caos, Orcos y Tyranidos, tanto porque puede sacar unidades demasiado rápidas a un bajo precio (Orcos, Tyranidos), como para transportar tropas cerca del enemigo (elfos y orkos ademas),
o expenderse muy rápido tambien. 
Si quieres jugar a tu ritmo están los Astra Militarum, Tau, Elfos y Necrones, ademas que cuesta expandirse dado que no se pueden colocar en cualquier lado por estos últimos excepto por los Tau y Astra que la mayoría cuenta con ataques de distancia para mantener lejos al enemigo en lo que vas explorando. Y se compensan con milicia mas fuerte y vehículos en el juego medio y final.
También las unidades que atacan de cerca con solo un rango de alcance son: Tyranidos, Adeptus Mecanicus, Orcos. El resto tiene un alcance de 2 o 3 ya que algunas unidades cuentan con sniper de facto, Elfos, Caos y creo que los Tau.
En fin, es un buen juego de estrategia, cuyo terreno es impredecible, ademas de que cambia bastante ya que cada facción tiene sus campeones con diferentes habilidades poder de fuego, defensa diferentes y puedes cambiarlo ahí mismo, ya que cuentan con tiendas para mejorar dentro del combate del mismo.
Las reliquias que te favorecen dando mas defensa, poder de fuego o lealtad, como la fauna con la que te tienes que abrir paso, dándole mas complejidad a este juego.
Si te gustan los juegos de Estrategia y quieres jugarlo, te lo recomiendo ya dándote una guía según sea tu estilo de juego.
si hay detalles que quieras agregar como algunas dudas si eres nuevo para disfrutar del juego, encantado de intentar responder tus dudas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055091370', 'num_games_owned': 417, 'num_reviews': 351, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 214, 'last_played': 1707754690}
review:
Odnoszę wrażenie, że ilość szans które dawałem do tej pory światowi Warhammera w różnych postaciach już dawno przekroczyła pewną granicę przyzwoitości. Sieciowe kooperacje, wersje planszowe, strzelaniny czasu rzeczywistego, taktyczne bitewniaki… Pomimo niewątpliwej rozległości i wielowątkowości tego uniwersum, jakoś nie znalazłem dla siebie miejsca w żadnej wariacji, a mimo to, trudno mówić o jakiejkolwiek słabnącej popularności wielkich, opancerzonych żołnierzy marines uposażonych w laserowe gnaty i miecze przypominające piły łańcuchowe. Tym razem na tapecie znalazła się strategia 4X, czyli coś co można zręcznie przekuć w bezbolesną inicjację, lub też koncertowo zepsuć poprzez niewłaściwe skupienie się na schedzie całej serii, zamiast atrakcyjnym gameplayu. W którą więc stronę idziemy?

Na pewno nie w kierunku zachęcającym do zostania fanem serii, co do tego nie mam najmniejszych wątpliwości. Przedstawiony świat pełen kosmitów, orków, generałów czy też demonów wydaje się być do tego stopnia niespójny, pozbawiony kontekstu oraz jakiejś takiej linii logicznej, że trudno wziąć to wszystko na poważnie i jakoś szczególnie polubić. Do bólu proste wprowadzenie oparte o kolonizację nowej planety, brak rozległych opisów dotyczących historii powstania danych jednostek albo ich roli w ekosystemie, a do tego zupełna nieobecność jakichś scenariuszy historycznych czy trybu fabularnego, który pozwoliłby nam bardziej polubić się z daną nacją albo odłamem kosmicznej mieszanki; tak jak nie byłem fanem kreacji Warhammera 40,000 przed rozpoczęciem rozgrywki, tak jej przebieg nieszczególnie mnie zachęcił, aby się w niego przeobrazić.

Co innego gameplay, który dość bezkompromisowo skierowano w konkretny target gracza, co moim zdaniem zawsze warto pochwalić i docenić. Bo choć ten konkretny gatunek kojarzymy raczej z powolną rozbudową, zarządzaniem heksagonalnymi polami, masą odkryć i decyzjami raczej stricte ekonomicznymi, tutaj przedstawiono sprawę bardzo jasno: “Chcecie odkrywać i eksplorować? Nie ma problemu, ale przede wszystkim macie się naparzać” - i to działa. Choć mamy co prawda jakieś tam budynki, odkrywanie technologii, zajmowanie przyczółków i całą tę otoczkę budowania potęgi planowania, to jednak główną rolę pełni zatrudnianie wojsk oraz bohaterów, ich ulepszanie, dozbrajanie, a finalnym parametrem zwycięstwa na koniec dnia zawsze zostaje fizyczna, wojenna dominacja, będąca jedynym dostępnym czynnikiem zwycięstwa. Proste, ale bardzo konsekwentne.

Tym bardziej, że aspekty prowadzenia rywalizacji bynajmniej nie są oczywiste i nudne w swoim przebiegu. Mamy tu różne typy jednostek, możliwe do wzmocnienia poprzez całą paletę odkryć naukowych, a same starcia prawie nigdy nie są zero-jedynkowe i przeważnie wymagają zaatakowania danego batalionu kilkoma grupami, by finalnie wyciąć każdego z jego członków w pień. Na mapie dzieje się całkiem sporo, szczególnie przy kilku frakcjach tłukących się ze sobą symultanicznie, natomiast systemy takie jak przyczółki zdobywane w łatwy sposób poprzez postawienie tam żołnierzy sprawiają, że kluczowe elementy planszy trzeba mieć nieustannie na oku i aktywnie dostosowywać się do panujących warunków.

Szkoda jedynie, że pomimo skupienia całej uwagi na konkretnym aspekcie, nie wzbogacono go dodatkowo o jakieś urozmaicenia z pogranicza wyzwań, losowych zdarzeń, czy chociażby możliwości optycznego dostosowania pól, nad którymi przejęliśmy kontrolę. Cały motyw historyczny sprowadzony został do znanego skądinąd szeregu misji stawianych przed nami od samego początku, które choć są obowiązkowe czy konieczne do odniesienia zwycięstwa, to jednak oferują dużą przewagę, a dodatkowo rzucają jakieś światło na stojące za każdą rasą motywy bądź aspiracje. O ile więc osobiście preferowałbym raczej jakąś kampanię, predestynowane potyczki albo ciekawe scenariusze z przerywnikami filmowymi, to dobrze, że dostajemy chociaż szansę poznania paru społeczności.

Celowo zresztą podkreślam, że przyjdzie nam obcować z jedynie kilkoma wspólnotami, gdyż pomimo całkiem pokaźnej liczby dostępnych stron konfliktu do wyboru, podstawowe wydanie gry zakłada jedynie cztery z nich, a całą resztę oferuje w formie opcjonalnych, płatnych(a jakże) DLC, których cena… nie należy do najbardziej adekwatnych, że tak pozwolę sobie łagodnie temat ująć. Bardzo odbiło się to zresztą na ocenie i recenzjach, ze względu na to że pomimo niewątpliwej wartości “podstawki”, w kontekście rozgrywania chociażby map z ośmioma uczestnikami, zwyczajnie brakuje jakiegoś elementu losowości i szansy na nietypowy rozkład sił na danym obszarze. Jak już jednak zdążyłem zauważyć, przede wszystkim rozchodzi się tu o ścieranie się produkowanymi na bieżąco armiami, więc choć nie popieram praktyki, to nie uważam, że sam koncept aż tak dużo na tym traci.

A grafika oraz udźwiękowienie? Całkowicie poprawne, to znaczy nie rzucające się szczególnie w oczy i nie zapadające jakoś spektakularnie w pamięć, co chyba należy rozpatrywać w kategorii atutu, biorąc pod uwagę z jakim typem zabawy się zmagamy. Fajnie działa dynamiczna zmiana nastroju wizualnego zależnie od każdego biomu, ale z drugiej strony plansze raczej nie są bardzo rozległe czy zróżnicowane, a dodatkowo nie zawierają w sobie jakichś cudów czy abominacji konstrukcyjnych. Zadziwiająco dużo satysfakcji oferują również animacje strzelania grup wojskowych - nie wiem do końca z czego to wynika, bo o ile ataki bezpośrednie czy chociażby manewry pojazdów prezentują się czasem nieco karykaturalnie, to kilkoro strzelców posyłających pociski i przerzedzających przeciwnika robi całkiem imponujące wrażenie za każdym razem gdy posyłamy ich do boju; jedynie dźwięki wystrzału bywają nieco zbyt głośne.

Reasumując, mamy przykład naprawdę solidnej, turowej pozycji, która została może nie tyle zrujnowana, co solidnie ogołocona przez dosyć płytką wartość fabularną oraz płatną zawartość w chyba trochę nieadekwatnej do treści cenie. Nadal jest to jednak ciekawa alternatywa dla konkurencyjnych pozycji, które zapewne niejednego adepta odstraszyły ogromną ilością polityki, ustaw, rozwoju technologicznego czy planowania rozbudowy imperium. Tutaj okrojono wszystkie te kwestie do absolutnego minimum, umożliwiając skupienie się w pełni na zarządzaniu zasobami ofensywnymi, bez niepotrzebnego zamartwiania się nad stanem naszego salda. A czy taki format wojennego młota Wam odpowiada czy też nie - na to już musicie odpowiedzieć sobie sami; ja doceniam, choć do zachwytu bardzo mi daleko.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005403195', 'num_games_owned': 232, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 934, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 934, 'last_played': 1707688893}
review:
I originally had this game on ignore and decided to pick it up when it was free on steam, so keep in mind that I am already biased based on that alone.

This game is like if you took a Civilisation game and striped it of everything but combat and then added city building back in. It's a weird turn based game that feels like it should be an RTS to me and while hero units that have special abilities are not confined to RTS games, they are certainly more prevalent in them. It lacks so much in the 4X area that I would never classify this as a 4X game.

As an example, none of the exploration of the ruins gives you a jump start on your faction, the ruins are there as a resource and give you a random hero buff. Which, out of the time I played, you can't even have a hero on turn one anyway making those random hero buffs useless until you research and build your first hero unit.

The combat is like a 4X in that it's just units bumping into each other with particle effects making lines from your unit to the enemy unit. So it nailed that part at least.

The unique resource nodes that generally are meant to be significant in a 4X game are anything but in Gladius. With the exception of two nodes, the majority only give you an extra resource bump, and minor at that. The two that are different are also disappointing in that one is a hero item shop and the other gives one unit that stops on top of it a +10% damage increase, which then triggers a 6 turn cooldown, if I remember right, on that node. And that is it. Hell, the hero item shop doesn't even seem to be randomised from the games I've played.

So the explore, expand, and exploit part of this game feels like an RTS as the map in any permutation is always the same. Where's the non-combat unit that helps improve infrastructure? Why can I not destroy enemy city tiles or at least incapacitate those tiles? Why should I try to produce more units than my opponent when most units can't shoot past two tiles and the units don't stack?

Gladius is shallow AND narrow.  

And with all that said, now look at the price and content in the DLCs.

TLDR: Save your money, this is not a 4X game. What game is here is shallow and you'll have experienced all the game has to offer in a single play through.

My primary gripe resides in the hefty price tag attached to the dlc's, which gate-keeps nearly two thirds of the roster and even some of the already available faction's troops/defenses. author: {'steamid': '76561198076244593', 'num_games_owned': 310, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 367, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 367, 'last_played': 1706651645}
review:
[h2] ENGLISH REVIEW [/h2]

The dlcs are pricey for what they offer and with but a small content return to the player. In itself, having only the base game leaves the player with an immense content limitation seen as some cut-content mechanics or specific troops from the base factions that the player has access to. Furthermore, a large part of the game interactions is present as combat against the wild life, mainly in the early to mid stages of the match's life, that is, the game pace itself is slow even sometimes when set to fast.

It is also worth mentioning that there is no 'campaign mode' in the game, with it only being integrated as some generic missions auto-generated within the match, if you choose to have them on during the creation of the map that is.

Also thanks to a review from a friend (@Astasia) it was brought to my attention that the concept of diplomacy between the factions during any match is also non-existent, even though the game is actually described within its store page as a 4X style strategic game, the same as the Civilization saga style.

[h2] PORTUGUÊS BRASILEIRO [/h2]

Cada dlc são um absurdo de caro para o Real brasileiro e com pouco retorno de conteúdo, e, em sí ter apenas o jogo base deixa o jogador com uma imensa limitação de conteúdo e corte de algumas mecânicas ou tropas nas facções iniciais. Além disso grande parte das interações do jogo está presente como combate contra a 'vida selvagem', principalmente no estágio inicial e mediano da vida da partida, ou seja, a partida em sí e lenta.

Vale também dizer que não há 'modo campanha' no jogo, sendo de uma forma integrada apenas como missões genéricas geradas dentro de uma partida, caso opte pela sua existência durante a criação do mapa. Graças a review de um amigo (@Astasia) foi levado a minha atenção que o conceito de diplomacia dentre as facções na partida também é inexistente, mesmo que o jogo realmente seja descrito em sua página da loja como um jogo estratégico estilo 4X, o mesmo estilo da saga Civilization.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004606215', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 20967, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 31, 'playtime_at_review': 18298, 'last_played': 1711939052}
review:
In this war game you will fight for supremacy of the planet Gladius. It is randomly generated each game, and you can adjust a huge array of settings for the map. It can be a desert world, ice world, river world, etc or a combination of all available biomes. Can't think of another game that has this many adjustments that effect so many aspects of play. 

The world is always hostile and dangerous. You will build cities that will provide research, resources, and the means to make the weapons of war. As you build up a force, you move out in a typical 4X fashion. Explore to find what is out there and where the enemy is. Exploit locations to benefit with outposts. Expand by building more cities or fortresses. Exterminate the enemy with prejudice. 

The games sounds effects and music are fantastic, Great graphics and just overall game atmosphere is wonderful in a dark way. It would have been nice to have individual voices for units, but there is an exceptional mod that has many factions covered now.

There is no diplomacy on Gladius, but you can set permanent teams on game setup. Some factions traditionally work together in the lore. But you don't need to know anything about WarHammer40k to understand game play. Each faction has a quest line, something of a campaign that you can enable and learn some lore and its unique systems. Not recommended to have set opponents for this mode unless you like allot of chaos. 

The games AI is at times very capable, far more than many others and they dont cheat unless you set the difficulty high. Injured units will withdraw if possible, they will set ambushes, use combined arms, and just all around appear to be managed by a modest human player. 

Each faction is unique in all ways, so playing a new faction will be a new game. The base game comes with four, so thats four ways of playing the game out of the box. Some have been critical of the numerous DLCs, and normally I would agree as in the case of Paradox and Creative Assembly's rampant abuse of the method, but I dont think that is the case here.

You get allot of content for the value in these DLCs, the faction DLC in particular. A faction DLC is a whole new army, unique mechanics, its own 10 level tech tree, and another campaign. Also consider GamesWorkshop gets its cut because they own WarHammer40k licence. They come on sale regularly, and if you are patient you'll save allot of your debased currency. I own 85% of the DLCs, and I bought them all at different times when on sale. 

Its an amazing game that holds true to the lore, decent tabletop translation for those people, and I fully recommend it for any 4X fan. The mod community has allot of good stuff now, be sure to check out the workshop if you get this game.

review:
Gladius is basically SidCiv but 40k and with no diplomacy, and I love it. It fits really well in with the rest of the mainstream 40k games while taking up an open spot in a broader strategy game. It has options to play almost every faction in the game (and hopefully they'll continue to update with more DLCs with the rest of the factions). 

But one of my other favorite aspects is the lore that they bring to the world of Gladius. The story is incredibly well written in my opinion and I haven't even finished the main story for each of the factions. It ties in Necrons with Aeldari, Tyranids with Mechanicus, and so on. Each of the races has a vested interest in holding the planet and you can follow any of them. There are different play styles for each of the factions but it isn't so different to the point where you need to spend time relearning how to play for each of them. You can really tell how much attention and dedication was put into the game, each of the units and structures look amazing and the world of Gladius really sells the idea of a hostile planet. All in all, absolutely recommend this game.

review: This game is one of the few strategy games that is fun on all levels. It is fun if you are just playing casually on the lowest difficulty just because you love 40k. It is also fun in a competitive online lobby where each player is attempting to pull of a specific efficient build order and play style as quick as possible. It threads the fine line of not feeling like you are trapped in a doomed game when you are being outpaced by adding in minor RNG elements to the map that can be customized to an extremely high level in the lobby. I would suggest finding an optimal settings layout before even beginning to play that fits your preferred play style. You can't ask for much more.

review: Eu sou um pai de 45 anos, provavelmente uma das pessoas mais velhas a jogar este jogo. Sou pai solteiro criando meu filho, que agora tem 15 anos. Meu filho ganhou este jogo no Natal de 2023 de seu tio, então o instalamos em seu computador e ele começou a jogar. Até o final da semana ele tinha 24 horas neste jogo. Isso foi horrível para mim, pois já era difícil encontrar maneiras de passar o tempo com meu filho, pois ele está sempre com os amigos ou apenas assistindo ao YouTube. Então eu decidi fazer uma conta no Steam e pegar esse jogo para ver se eu poderia jogar ao lado dele. Eu comprei o jogo, escolhi minha skin e mundo e comecei a jogar, mas eu estava preso no que você deveria fazer. Pedi ajuda ao meu filho e ele organizou um jogo para eu participar. Adorei, pois foi o melhor momento que passei com meu filho desde que minha esposa morreu. Desde então, esse jogo aproximou eu e meu filho novamente e agora passamos um tempo juntos fora de casa também. Este jogo me lembrou que há diversão em tudo, e trouxe muitas lembranças felizes para mim e meu filho.

author: {'steamid': '76561198998437307', 'num_games_owned': 128, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 527, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 289, 'last_played': 1704786120}
review:
Как человек из старого еврейского рода, а по совместительству - житель "культурной" столицы (а иными словами города у Невы) я заявляю, что я poт труба шатал этой игры и её обучения! В первый раз захожу и меня уже eб#т тау и их прихвостни, а когда я с трудом наладил экономику и загнал синих коммунистов подальше - восстали машины без имён и лиц. Души мёртвых, заточенные в живой металл. Их пробуждения час настал. Из забытья вернулся в мир - безмолвный ужас некронтир. Моё сердце познало страх - пyкaн мой обратился в прах. И вот неся всему живому смерть К'тан пришли как страшный сон. И все мои точки были захвачены и держал я оборону в своей крепости, а после перешёл в конт-атаку. Уничтожил аванпост, ещё один и вот мой капитан встал напротив порабащённого владыки - К'тан смотрел ему в лицо развоплотив осадный танк и готовясь омыть своё тело из некродермиса кровью ультрадесантника и начался бой. Астартес стреляли в технонежить, а она отвечала огнём гаусса. И после множества ходов - К'тан сгинул, а капитан склонился над его телом, весь израненный и на последнем издыхании и в его спину ударил луч гаусса ужасающей силы. Ничто его не могло спасти, но он не сожалел, он выполнил свой долг и понимал, что внёс вклад в победу над древней угрозой.
Тут у меня бомбануло и я отрубил комп. Отличная игра. Всем советую. Eб#л я её и она меня.

review:
Great game, I love turn based tile games and this game really brings the feeling of massive wars in the late game/turns of WH40K and you actually need a bit of strategy thinking, you can also play most of the factions from the universe of WH40K here (I especially love Adepta Sororitas/Sisters of Battle) and It's great game with friends especially if you've got a big group to play with, but it's also fun playing alone but can get boring after a while, so get it with friends.

I also love the Balancing of the factions even the DLC ones so It's not quite Pay 2 win, however what I dislike is that your true enemy is not the opposite faction that you have to kill but is the wildlife, they obviously will not be too big of a deal if you kill them off in the late game but It can sometimes even ruin your gameplay, that's just one thing I don't like about it, I wish we'd have some sort of option to disable wildlife just to experience the war against other factions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198318001083', 'num_games_owned': 490, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 4680, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3031, 'last_played': 1705148798}
review:
50小时测评：玩法类似文明的回合制策略游戏，但是阵营之间只能通过征服取胜，不同阵营玩法区别很大，初始4阵营有点少，各个增强包可以按喜好购买，除了最终兵器外其他单位之间有明显的克制关系。

游玩过程中前期主打跑图清野，用英雄单位伴随小兵打遭遇战。然后铺城用数值更高的单位来替换炮灰，中后期形成完整的作战体系，与多方拉扯破城，最后大后期最终兵器平推。实际玩起来除了个别小兵有反大反装甲能力，基本上就是谁高级单位等级高，数值多就能拼赢。玩法说实话就是堆数值，所以一旦对兵种了解之后玩法就比较无聊了。

游戏整体难度波动较大，可以按自己喜好设定。值得一提的是野怪和AI使用的单位会随着dlc的购买而变得多样。
游戏最大的缺点就是新鲜感不足，很多阵营真的就是试一把就再也不碰，阵营自带的任务几乎一模一样没有一点区别，任务给的奖励也是差不多的。英雄单位有装备系统但是装备是通用的，没有阵营专属武器。

整体来看大约能给个8分，之后追加其他dlc的评价。
阵营体验如下
帝国：手长，能建要塞，什么兵种都有一点，很踏实的阵营

星际战士：突出单兵能力，医疗兵生产容易，步兵前期防守很强，资源获取偏少，且拓张速度慢。

太空死灵：单位恢复力惊人，输出也不俗，前期发育慢，中期开始发力。

兽人：无脑冲锋的阵营，反步兵能力优秀，对空很弱。以战养战，城市内圈输出爆炸。

dlc阵营：

战斗修女：介于介于卫队和星际战士之间的存在，步坦协同能力优秀，发展简单，适合新手。
dlc推荐程度：必买

机械神教：城市发展缓慢，科研需要手动改善，不然科技树爬的很慢，载具性能不错。
dlc推荐程度：一般

方舟世界艾达灵族：铺城随缘且位置固定，单位可以通过网道门快速传送，步兵脆弱但是伤害不俗，适合伏击，坦克可以应对各种情况，前期需要小心外，整体强度尚可。后期单位数值很高，对新手不友好。
dlc推荐程度：一般

黑暗灵族：上述阵营的翻版，网道传送能力进一步加强，步兵手长且不脆。部队机动性较强，正面硬拼实力一般。
dlc推荐程度：较推荐

钛帝国：精通远距离作战的种族，几乎不依赖近战，且大部分单位无视铁线草。缺点是操作复杂，且单位面板数值一般，建议一同购入额外兵种dlc。
dlc推荐程度：较推荐

泰伦虫族：操作难度天花板的阵营，前期极弱，换来的是极高的发育速度以及几乎无敌的后期兵种（攻高血厚跑得快打的远还自动回血。）除兽人外第二个人海战术的种族。
dlc推荐程度：必买
